tossups.question: The wavefunction for the quantum variant of this system is given by Mathieu (“ma-TEE-yoo”) functions. Bringing a variant of this system from one equilibrium point to another is the goal of an acrobot. In a phenomenon studied by Pyotr Kapitza (“p’yo-ter ka-pizza”), an inverted one of these systems is stabilized by vigorously shaking the base. This system can be solved from any initial position using elliptic integrals of the first kind. Two of these systems linked together create a classic example of (*) chaos theory. When this system is linearized by the small angle approximation, its period is proportional to “the square root of L over G.” A variant of this system with a length just under 1 meter will take 1 second for each half-swing in a mechanism that drives grandfather clocks. For 10 points, name this system consisting of a swinging bob suspended from a string.
tossups.answer: simple pendulums [or simple pendula; accept quantum pendulum, double pendulum, inverted pendulum, or Kapitza pendulum; prompt on simple harmonic oscillator, simple harmonic motion, or SHO before mentioned]

tossups.question: High grade examples of this material were historically synthesized with the Acheson process using higher temperatures to remove boron impurities and minimize its millibarns. The release of Wigner (“VIG-ner”) energy stored in defects in this material’s lattice ultimately ignited one of the cartridges pushed through it at Windhaven. The German nuclear program failed largely because it used heavy water instead of this material, which made up 88% of Chicago Pile-1 by weight. This material is commonly ground up and used as an industrial lubricant and is a common (*) neutron moderator. Household sellotape can be used to separate the hexagonal layers of this material. tossups.answer: graphite [accept plumbago or nuclear graphite; prompt on carbon; anti-prompt on graphene; prompt on nuclear waste with “what material was it before it was nuclear waste?”]

This painting’s right panel features a (*) “Tree Man” in front of a large pair of ears carrying a knife. Its middle panel depicts countless nude figures cavorting with oversized animals and fruits. For 10 points, name this insane triptych depicting humanity giving into sin and being punished in hell, the magnum opus of Hieronymus Bosch (“high-RON-a-muss BOSH”)

parts: Name this country. Despite being from this country himself, Jean-Jacques Rousseau criticized this country’s tradition of tragédie en musique (“tra-jay-DEE on moo-ZEEK”), or musical tragedy.

French musical tragedy was introduced by this composer, who was pitted against Jean-Philippe Rameau in an earlier culture war. This composer died of gangrene after stabbing his foot with his conductor’s baton.

answers_sanitized: astrocytes [or astroglia or astrocytic glial cells]
parts: Name these glial (“GLEE-al”) cells that express GFAP (“G-F-A-P”) in the central nervous system. “Reactive” variants of these cells create glial scars in response to the destruction of nearby neurons.

The end-feet of astrocytes (“astro-sites”) push against the endothelial (“en-do-THEE-lee-al”) cells of this structure, which keeps large or hydrophilic (“hydro-FILL-ick”) molecules from entering the central nervous system.
Astrocytes are thought to release gliotransmitters in response to this element’s 2+ ion. Dairy products are a good dietary source of this element’s 2+ ion, which is stored in bone.

bonuses.leadin: This construct is sometimes named for its three constant variables, N, V, and E. For 10 points each:

answers: microcanonical ensemble [do not accept or prompt on “canonical ensemble” or “grand canonical ensemble”]
answers_sanitized: microcanonical ensemble [do not accept or prompt on “canonical ensemble” or “grand canonical ensemble”]
parts: Name this construct derived by taking the density of microstates in a certain energy range, then taking the limit as the range of energies goes to zero. This construct assumes that all microstates have equal probability.

Ludwig Boltzmann used the microcanonical ensemble to define this quantity as his namesake constant times the logarithm of the number of microstates. It measures the amount of disorder in a system, and never decreases, according to the second law of thermodynamics.
Unlike other ensembles, the microcanonical ensemble allows for these processes in systems of any size. Types of these processes that do not involve latent heat are termed “continuous.”
